lg.l: Parais Deorum cultor et Infrequens,
Consultus────────────
OS───t! why shou'd you who art wiser indeed,
Than Modern Deans───who can Write and can Read
Why shou'd you then trouble your self with such Things,
As M────es, D────rs, or De────ty K────gs?
If these be the Subjects of J──────n's Pen,
No more will we call him the wisest of Men;
No more we'll his Freedom on BOXES of Gold,
No more we'll his Picture on Sign Posts behold────
Why shou'd you then J──────n trouble your Pate,With begging Epistles, or Matters of State?

Let the D────r be stupidly fond of his Letters, And dull with Impertinance trouble his Betters:Let him Cringe, Lie, and Flatter, and do what he can,(Those Arts seldom fail to win a Great Man)Let him practice 'em over and over again,He'll find he is a Reader of Books, not of Men.
The D────r, it may be, believes himself scanted,
In poor pretty Hundreds, when Thousands he wanted;
He knows that his Merits are equal to any,
For who's not acquainted with D────r D────y?
I believe there are few who won't think it Insanum,
That the Doctor's possess'd of five Hundred per Annum;
Or, Merit like his, shou'd be look'd on no better,
Or Answer be made to his Excellent LETTER:
These, these, are the Effects of the Times we must know,
For this Way it was not some Hundreds ago.

But why in good Troth shou'd such Whim'eys as These, Be ever remember'd in J──────n's Lays?No more let such Trifles your Hours Employ,No more let such Subjects your Virtue Destroy:Take this from a Friend, be Good as you'r Wise,Nor think as a Church-man, you ever will rise,'Till my Wise Dean you'll give over your LIBEL,Apply to RELIGION, and think on the BIBLE.────
